results.title: Virginia Woolf's criticism of the novel 'Life escapes'
results.creator_credit: Richard Callanan, Open University and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The 19th Century Novel”.
Following a dramatised scene from Virginia Woolf’s novel “Life Escapes”, Professor Arnold Kettle argues that Virginia Woolf was not just telling a story but recreating an era of reality and this leads her to break with the traditional form of the novel in a way which emphasises the moment-to-moment impressions of life.
results.title_for_label: Virginia Woolf’s criticism of the novel ‘Life escapes’

results.title: Forster and Lawrence
results.creator_credit: Alasdair Clayre and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The 19th Century Novel”.
Richard Hoggart discusses with Graham Martin the contrast between the prose style of D.H. Lawrence and E.M. Forster, with particular reference to the “Fox” and “Where Angels Fear to Tread”.

group_works.title: Harvest at Nong Lub
group_works.creator_credit: Brian Hannant, Thanom Soongnarata, John Morris and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Harvest at Nong Lub
results.creator_credit: Brian Hannant, Thanom Soongnarata, John Morris and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Thailand”.
Without intruding, an Australian camera crew lives with a Thai family during the rice harvest. The comings and goings, the hard work, the moments of relaxation, the dreams and also the aspirations are briefly held in the hope of understanding the differences in life and the similarities in being

results.title: The Students (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Anthony Cash, Roger Owen and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Teaching Adults”
This program looks briefly at the “consumers” of voluntary adult education. It stresses the variety of courses they pursue and especially their own diversity. An adult class is not homogeneous, there are varieties in age, educational background, experience and social class. In many situations (notably craft classes) this tends to lead to individual teaching (which can be uneconomical in terms of the use of a teacher’s time).

results.title: The Organisers
results.creator_credit: Anthony Cash, Roger Owen and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Teaching Adults”.
How far do organisers think in educational terms? Have they a philosophy of adult education? Do they know the environment they serve? Are they concerned with the actual quality of the teaching that goes on in their area or college.

results.title: Adults as learners. No. 2 (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Anthony Cash, Roger Owen and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Teaching Adults”.
Demonstrates in a machine shop situation how blind workers are taught. A practising artist explains to a group of varying ages and educational background the fundamentals of abstract art.

results.title: Adults as learners. No. 1 (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Anthony Cash, Roger Owen and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Teaching Adults”.
Examples of formal teaching and teaching by discovery with two groups of British Railways workers learning elementary electricity. A lesson on chess for a beginner, by the discovery method, is used to support the discussion.
